description: From Middle English beknowen, biknowen, from Old English becnāwan (“to know, know about”), equivalent to be- +‎ know. Cognate with Old High German bichnāan (“to recognise, see”).

verbs.description: beknow (third-person singular simple present beknows, present participle beknowing, simple past beknew, past participle beknown)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To know about; have knowledge of; recognise; understand; be aware (of); be knowledgeable about.
examples: At length Alkimedon, his friend and comrade, right beknew it; [...]
